transcript: - I've been doing tech news for seven years now. And I swear if I see one more tech story, I'm gonna tell you about it, gladly! Dealing with popups from antivirus bloatware, like McAfee on new laptops, is annoying. But if you're involved in the US election, it might actually be dangerous to something other than your own mental health. A new report from Google indicates that a Chinese hacker group dubbed, APT31 has been impersonating McAfee employees with the goal of infiltrating computers used by campaign workers. APT31 used phishing tactics to try and get staffers to install McAfee products from GitHub, instead of the official McAfee website, which to be fair, just as sketchy, if not more. And these downloads also contain malware which could be invisible to the end user. Google says this is part of a larger trend of government backed malware attacks, which have increased as 2020 has gone on. The upcoming presidential election in the US is no doubt, a huge impetus for these attacks. And here I was thinking attack ads were the worst part of election season. Ha! Not this year, this is the hell year. Everything's worse. - [Guy] It's only gonna get worse. - Just you wait. Today, they unveiled a wireless charger that can deliver 80 Watts, which is more than the power bricks for a lot of mainstream laptops. - [Guy] That's a lot of Watts - Wow! That's a lot of Watts, Marty! Xiaomi claims that its new product can wirelessly charge a 4,000 milliamp hour battery in just 19 minutes, as well as get from zero to 50 in less than nine minutes, which would be quite impressive indeed. Although there are faster charging solutions around, this appears to be the fastest wireless one yet, although we're not yet sure exactly when it's going to hit the market. In the meantime, remember to plug your phone in before you pass out, just in case, when it hits the mark when it hits the market and then you're gonna pass out. So it'll be interesting to see how the cars perform. The test-- - [Guy] them go uphill. - (laughs) They can actually do it. The tests will be limited to just one neighborhood for the time being.
